sections.title: The Certainty and Wisdom of Death

verses.text: O death, how bitter is the thought of you to one at peace among his possessions, to a man undisturbed and who prospers in all things, and is still able to enjoy food!
verses.comment: This verse reflects the deep discomfort the prosperous feel when contemplating death. Prosperity can create an illusion of security apart from God. See also James 1:10-11 for a similar theme.
verses.sectionHeader: The Certainty and Wisdom of Death

verses.text: O death, how welcome is your sentence to one who is needy and failing in strength, worn down by age and anxious about everything; to one who is contrary, and has lost all patience!
verses.comment: This verse captures the ancient Jewish wisdom tradition's realism about suffering—death is presented not only as an adversary, but as a welcome release for the deeply afflicted, echoing Job 3:20-22 and underscoring the Bible’s acknowledgment of existential burdens.

verses.text: Do not fear death’s decree for you; remember those who went before you and those who will come after.
verses.comment: In contrast to the prosperous, the suffering may long for death as relief. Suffering can cause a yearning for God's final justice.

verses.text: Do not fear death's judgment; remember those who came before you and those who will come after. This is the decree from the Lord for all flesh.
verses.comment: Here, death is seen as the unifying fate of mankind. Hebrews 9:27 echoes this: it is appointed to men once to die, then judgment.

verses.text: The children of sinners are abominable children, and they frequent the haunts of the ungodly.
verses.comment: The reference to 'children of sinners' reflects the ancient belief in communal and generational consequences for sin (cf. Exodus 20:5), warning that association with wickedness leads to moral and social degeneration.

verses.text: The inheritance of the children of sinners will perish, and on their offspring will be a perpetual disgrace.
verses.comment: A warning echoing the curses for covenant unfaithfulness. Earthly treasures are shown to be fleeting compared to spiritual blessings.

verses.text: Children will blame an ungodly father, for they suffer disgrace because of him.
verses.comment: The erasure of a wicked person's name foreshadows the concept of the 'book of life' and ultimate judgment.

verses.text: Woe to you, the ungodly, who have forsaken the law of the Most High God!
verses.comment: Forsaking the law of God is a central biblical indictment (see Psalm 1 and Deuteronomy 28), emphasizing the seriousness of apostasy in Jewish wisdom literature and its inevitable consequences for the ungodly.

verses.text: If you have children, calamity will be theirs; you will beget them only for groaning. When you stumble, there is lasting joy; and when you die, a curse is your lot.
verses.comment: This verse reinforces the idea that the wicked bring trouble not only upon themselves but also upon their descendants, echoing prophetic themes (e.g., Jeremiah 16:3-4) about the cascading effects of abandoning God’s covenant.

verses.text: Whatever comes from earth returns to earth; so the ungodly go from curse to destruction.
verses.comment: Disgrace and loss are depicted as the true inheritance for those who reject God's way.

verses.text: The human body is a fleeting thing, but a virtuous name will never be blotted out.
verses.comment: Personal sin has communal ramifications. The consequences of one's choices ripple through even generations.

verses.text: Have regard for your name, since it will outlive you longer than a thousand hoards of gold.
verses.comment: A direct address to the rebellious, echoing warnings found in the Psalms and Romans.

verses.text: The days of a good life are numbered, but a good name lasts forever.
verses.comment: The curse for disobedience described here finds its roots in the blessings and curses of Deuteronomy.

verses.text: My children, be true to your training and be at peace; hidden wisdom and unseen treasure—of what value is either?
verses.comment: Mortality returns all flesh to the dust, but for the ungodly, this is united with a spiritual fate.

verses.text: Better are those who hide their folly than those who hide their wisdom.
verses.comment: Memory is tied to the spiritual legacy we leave behind. Sinners have no lasting memorial before God.

verses.text: Therefore show respect for my words; for it is not good to feel shame in every circumstance, nor is every kind of abashment to be approved.
verses.comment: A good name, or character, is a spiritual legacy more precious than riches, recalling the proverb about a good name.

verses.text: Be ashamed of sexual immorality, before your father or mother; and of a lie, before a prince or a ruler;
verses.comment: The enduring nature of virtue is affirmed—pointing to everlasting rewards for righteousness.

verses.text: Be ashamed of a crime, before a judge or magistrate; and of a breach of the law, before the congregation and the people; of unjust dealing, before your partner or your friend;
verses.comment: Sirach provides practical social guidance: public shame is appropriate for wrongdoing before relevant authorities, reflecting the community’s role in moral formation and analogous to Jesus’ exhortations about reconciliation in Matthew 5:23-24.

verses.text: and of theft, in the place where you live. Be ashamed of breaking an oath or agreement, and of leaning on your elbow at meals; of surliness in receiving or giving,
verses.comment: The wisdom tradition enumerates various forms of social impropriety and dishonesty—ranging from theft to breaking oaths—highlighting the importance of personal integrity and good conduct within one’s immediate context.

verses.text: and of silence, before those who greet you; of looking at a prostitute,
verses.comment: Sirach prescribes sensitivity to social norms, including common courtesies such as returning greetings, and cautions against sexual impropriety, which aligns with prohibitions found in Proverbs and Leviticus 19:29.

verses.text: and of rejecting the appeal of a relative; of taking away someone’s portion or gift, and of gazing at another man’s wife;
verses.comment: There is a particular focus on protecting familial and social bonds—rejecting relatives, coveting another’s wife, or taking another’s share breaks trust and echoes commandments in Exodus 20.

verses.text: of meddling with his servant-girl — and do not approach her bed; of abusive words, before friends — and do not be insulting after making a gift.
verses.comment: The concern for sexual boundaries and speech continues; meddling with servants or using words to insult after generosity violates social ethics, paralleling warnings against exploiting the vulnerable and the call to restrained speech in Proverbs 15:1.
